docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama cruised into office with an aura of mellow cool, a Zen attitude that colleagues and friends attributed to his Hawaii upbringing, the Aloha Spirit of his native state.

headline.main: White House Tense as Clock Ticks on Health Care Bill

docs.abstract: As health care talks come down the wire, the White House is anything but Zen.
docs.snippet: As health care talks come down the wire, the White House is anything but Zen.

docs.lead_paragraph: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
docs.abstract: A push to lower drug costs, service complaints from Google smartphone customers and other consumer-focused items from Wednesday's Times.
docs.snippet: A push to lower drug costs, service complaints from Google smartphone customers and other consumer-focused items from Wednesday's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama and Senator Harry Reid hold their first face-to-face meeting on Wednesday since the controversy erupted over comments that Mr. Reid once made about Mr. Obama's race and dialect. But that topic is not on the Oval Office agenda. Health care is.

headline.main: Obama, Congressional Leaders Resume Push on Health Care

docs.abstract: The White House and lawmakers have a new worry over health care -- the fate of the special election in Massachusetts.
docs.snippet: The White House and lawmakers have a new worry over health care -- the fate of the special election in Massachusetts.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wall Street executives at the helms of bailed out banks are on the hot seat this morning for the first hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission.

headline.main: The Early Word: Economic Inquiry Begins

docs.abstract: Wall Street executives at the helms of bailed out banks are on the hot seat this morning for the first hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission.
docs.snippet: Wall Street executives at the helms of bailed out banks are on the hot seat this morning for the first hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission.

docs.lead_paragraph: Today, the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, which Congress established last year to investigate the causes of the financial crisis, is scheduled to question the heads of four big banks - Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian Moynihan of Bank of America.

headline.main: More Questions for the Finance Chiefs

docs.lead_paragraph: Since 2008, injury and illness have interfered with Karen Rashford’s steady employment in the health care field. She has had to turn to public assistance.
